# Webhooks quickstart

Webhook sources let your applications push webhook events into
Materialize. This quickstart uses an embedded **webhook event
generator** that makes it easier for you to learn and prototype with no
external dependencies.

<div class="tip">

**ðŸ’¡ Tip:** For help getting started with your own data, you can
schedule a [free guided
trial](https://materialize.com/demo/?utm_campaign=General&utm_source=documentation).

</div>

## Before you begin

All you need is a Materialize account. If you already have one â€” great!
If not, [sign up for a free trial
account](https://materialize.com/register/?utm_campaign=General&utm_source=documentation)
first.

When youâ€™re ready, head over to the [Materialize
console](/docs/self-managed/v25.2/console/), and pop open the SQL Shell.

## Step 1. Create a secret

To validate requests between the webhook event generator and
Materialize, you need a
[secret](/docs/self-managed/v25.2/sql/create-secret/):

<div class="highlight">

``` chroma
CREATE SECRET demo_webhook AS '<secret_value>';
```

</div>

Change the `<secret_value>` to a unique value that only you know and
store it in a secure location.

## Step 2. Set up a webhook source

Using the secret from the previous step, create a webhook source to
ingest data from the webhook event generator. By default, the source
will be created in the current cluster.

<div class="highlight">

``` chroma
CREATE SOURCE webhook_demo FROM WEBHOOK
  BODY FORMAT JSON
  CHECK (
    WITH (
      HEADERS,
      BODY AS request_body,
      SECRET demo_webhook AS validation_secret
    )
    -- The constant_time_eq validation function **does not support** fully
    -- qualified secret names. We recommend always aliasing the secret name
    -- for ease of use.
    constant_time_eq(headers->'x-api-key', validation_secret)
  );
```

</div>

After a successful run, the command returns a `NOTICE` message
containing the unique [webhook
URL](/docs/self-managed/v25.2/sql/create-source/webhook/#webhook-url)
that allows you to `POST` events to the source. Copy and store it. You
will need it for the next step.

## Step 3. Generate webhook events

The webhook event generator uses [Faker.js](https://fakerjs.dev/) under
the covers, which means you can use any of the [supported
modules](https://fakerjs.dev/api/) to shape the events.

<div id="webhooks-datagen" class="json_widget">

<div class="input_container">

<div class="input_container-text">

</div>

</div>

<div class="input_container">

<div class="input_container-text">

</div>

</div>

<div class="input_container">

<div class="input_container-text">

Generate webhook events!

Stop

</div>

</div>

<div class="input_container">

<div class="input_container-text">

Select a Faker.js module Sensor data User activity E-commerce
transaction

</div>

</div>

<div>

<div class="json">

<div id="jsonError" class="error" style="display: none">

</div>

</div>

<div id="logOutput" class="log_output" style="display: none">

</div>

</div>

</div>

In the SQL Shell, validate that the source is ingesting data:

<div class="highlight">

``` chroma
SELECT jsonb_pretty(body) AS body FROM webhook_demo LIMIT 1;
```

</div>

As an example, if you use the `Sensor data` module of the webhook event
generator, the data will look like:

<div class="highlight">

``` chroma
{
  "location": {
    "latitude": 6,
    "longitude": 0
  },
  "sensor_id": 48,
  "temperature": 89.38,
  "timestamp": "2029-10-07T10:44:13.456Z"
}
```

</div>

## Step 4. Parse JSON

Manually parsing JSON-formatted data in SQL can be tedious. ðŸ«  You can
use the widget below to **automatically** turn a sample JSON payload
into a parsing view with the individual fields mapped to columns.

<div class="json_widget">

<div class="json">

<div id="error_span" class="error">

</div>

</div>

<span class="input_container"> <span class="input_container-text">
</span> </span>

Target object type View Materialized view

``` sql_output
```

</div>

Webhook data is ingested as a JSON blob. We recommend creating a parsing
view on top of your webhook source that uses [jsonb
operators](/docs/self-managed/v25.2/sql/types/jsonb/#operators) to map
the individual fields to columns with the required data types. Using the
previous example:

<div class="highlight">

``` chroma
CREATE VIEW webhook_demo_parsed AS SELECT
    (body->'location'->>'latitude')::numeric AS location_latitude,
    (body->'location'->>'longitude')::numeric AS location_longitude,
    (body->>'sensor_id')::numeric AS sensor_id,
    (body->>'temperature')::numeric AS temperature,
    try_parse_monotonic_iso8601_timestamp(body->>'timestamp') AS timestamp
FROM webhook_demo;
```

</div>

## Step 5. Subscribe to see the output

To see results change over time, letâ€™s
[`SUBSCRIBE`](/docs/self-managed/v25.2/sql/subscribe/) to the
`webhook_demo_parsed ` view:

<div class="highlight">

``` chroma
SUBSCRIBE(SELECT * FROM webhook_demo_parsed) WITH (SNAPSHOT = FALSE);
```

</div>

Youâ€™ll see results change as new webhook events are ingested. When
youâ€™re done, cancel out of the `SUBSCRIBE` using **Stop streaming**.

## Step 6. Clean up

Once youâ€™re done exploring the generated webhook data, remember to clean
up your environment:

<div class="highlight">

``` chroma
DROP SOURCE webhook_demo CASCADE;

DROP SECRET demo_webhook;
```

</div>

## Next steps

To get started with your own data, check out the [reference
documentation](/docs/self-managed/v25.2/sql/create-source/webhook/) for
the webhook source.

</div>
